This explains the words of the aforementioned Midrash where Yehudah said, "Is this what you meant by 'setting your eyes'? The matter has been reversed - what you said was actually [meant for] blinding our eyes." For it states in Bereishit Rabbah (Chapter 93) that Yehudah said, "Know that you came upon us with a false pretense from the beginning. How many provinces came down here to buy food? Did you ask any of them what you asked us? Were you perhaps seeking your daughter or your sister from us? Nevertheless, 'we said to my master,' etc., and we concealed nothing."

At first glance, we need to understand why they didn't realize from the beginning that he was coming upon them with a false pretense. How did they not see the difference and distinction he made with them compared to all other peoples who came before him? And why did they tell him all their affairs and conceal nothing from him?

However, all this was a decree from Heaven that they should not understand the true nature of the pretense, so that they would bring Binyamin and the matter of their descent to Egypt would unfold. Therefore, it was caused by Hashem that Yosef's words were spoken to them in a way that blinded their eyes, so that they wouldn't investigate to understand their true meaning. This was not natural but rather a divine cause clothed in nature.

Now when Yehudah approached to speak harshly to Yosef, even though they still hadn't grasped the truth of the matters and their inner meaning wasn't revealed until Yosef made himself known to them, they did realize that all his words were in the nature of "blinding of the eyes." For otherwise, it would be unnatural that they would be caught and believe all his words without doubting them, to the point that they told him everything he asked and concealed nothing.

This is what the Midrash means when it says that Yehudah said, "Is this what you meant by 'setting your eyes'? Initially, this wasn't your intention. The matter has been reversed and it's become clear that all this was a blinding of the eyes."

This now resolves the Ramban's question (the third question) that this isn't a valid argument for exemption after being suspected of theft. According to our approach, Yehudah's argument wasn't about this at all, but rather his entire complaint was that "from the beginning you came with a false pretense, and when you said 'I will set my eyes upon him,' that wasn't your real intention - it was [meant for] blinding our eyes to prepare a false pretense against us." "For I am the one speaking to you" - Rashi explains [this means] in the Holy Tongue (Hebrew). The Ramban, of blessed memory, challenged this interpretation, saying this is not proof that he was their brother, as many in Egypt knew that language. For Egypt was close to the land of Canaan, and especially for a ruler, as it is the way of kings and rulers to know languages. Just as Joseph came from Canaan to Egypt, it's possible that many others came and also knew that language.

The Mizrachi and the Gur Aryeh further challenged the proof from circumcision, saying it's not complete proof, since all Ishmaelites are circumcised, as well as all of Abraham's descendants through Keturah. Even the Egyptians were circumcised during the years of famine, as Rashi explains (based on Bereishit Rabbah) on the verse "Go to Joseph; what he tells you, do."

The Mizrachi resolves this by explaining that although neither proof is sufficient on its own, when combined they provide definitive proof. For circumcision was not found among the Canaanites who spoke the Holy Tongue, and the descendants of Ishmael and Keturah who were circumcised did not speak the Holy Tongue. With just one sign, one could say it's coincidental - perhaps he's from the children of Keturah (explaining the circumcision), or perhaps he's from Canaan (explaining the language), and not Joseph. But the combination of both signs occurring together would be highly unlikely, and therefore the combination of circumcision and language together serves as definitive proof. This is the essence of the Mizrachi's words, and the Gur Aryeh wrote similarly but in a different way, see there.

We can explain the words of the Midrash (mentioned earlier in the previous discourse) on "And you shall go up in peace to your father." They said to him that this peace is entirely "nishpah" (the Yefat To'ar explains this as darkness, like "neshef" in Scripture, meaning this is a peace of darkness and gloom). Yet the Ruach HaKodesh [Divine Spirit] calls out "Great peace have they who love Your Torah."

This can be explained according to our approach: Yehudah and Yosef were arguing with each other, and the opposition between them was so great that Yehudah wanted to destroy all of Egypt, as explained by our Sages. Therefore, they said this peace is entirely "nishpah" - how can this be called peace when it is a peace of darkness and gloom?

However, all their arguments were for the sake of truth, and "both these and these are the words of the living God." Their disagreement was regarding halacha [Jewish law] and according to the laws of the Torah, as explained by the Pardes and other commentators. Such a disagreement will ultimately lead to peace, as indeed happened with them.

This is what the Ruach HaKodesh means by "Great peace have they who love Your Torah" - this is true peace when each of the disputants' desire and goal is only to understand the true meaning of the holy Torah. This is what the Midrash Tanchuma means when it says "And he sent Yehudah before him... yesterday they were butting heads with each other, and now he sends him to him - this exemplifies 'He who makes peace in His heights.'" This type of peace was a heavenly influence and based on truth, like the nature of peace in the upper realms. Understand this.

At first glance, how can one refer to the Torah as merely a "remnant" [shiyur]? Similar to what I explained regarding the verse where Yaakov Avinu (our father Jacob) said to Lavan, "With whomever you find your gods, he shall not live," and from that curse Rachel died on the way. At first glance, how could it be that Yaakov Avinu uttered a curse, and how did he not worry that perhaps his wives or children had taken the terafim (idols), as was indeed the case that Rachel had taken them?

I explained that Yaakov Avinu was precise in his language to avoid uttering a curse, Heaven forbid. Therefore, he didn't say "whoever has your gods in their possession shall not live," rather he said "with whomever you find your gods," and Yaakov Avinu knew that Lavan wouldn't find them. I've explained this in various other ways as well (see our words on Parshat Vayetzei).

However, since to the eye and according to the simple meaning of his words, it appeared as if he was cursing whoever had the avodah zarah (idolatry) in their possession, therefore the curse found a place to take effect and Rachel died on the way. This is similar to what our Sages said that a wise man's curse, even if conditional, comes to pass, because his speech makes an impression even if he didn't intend it.

Similarly in our matter, since Yehudah's words appeared outwardly as a curse, his bones were consequently scattered, because a wise man's curse, even if conditional, makes an impression. Following our approach, this resolves the question of the Ra'avad and other commentators of why Yehudah didn't annul his nidui (ban). It is known that the way of tzaddikim (righteous ones) is to always attribute deficiency to themselves, and they suspect themselves of not yet having reached perfection. Therefore, according to Yehudah's knowledge and understanding, he didn't need annulment, because he knew through ruach hakodesh (Divine inspiration) at the time of the nidui that he would be able to fulfill his condition, and he wasn't concerned about the principle that a wise man's curse comes to pass even if conditional, because he didn't consider himself to be on such a level that his words would make an impression in every case.

Through this we can understand regarding our matter that initially, Yosef made himself a stranger to them and appeared to them as an Egyptian man. Therefore, when he asked them "Is your elderly father well, is he still alive?", they responded simply "he is still alive." Their intention in answering was based on their understanding of his question regarding physical life, as common people and materialistic beings would understand it.

However, now that he revealed himself to them and said "I am Yosef, is my father still alive?", they understood that his question wasn't about physical life, but rather about the level of the Shechinah's (Divine Presence's) dwelling with him, which was his true life-force due to his great level of holiness. This is similar to what our Sages interpreted on the verse "and the spirit of their father Yaakov was revived," which Rashi explains (from the Midrash Rabbah) that the Shechinah, which had departed from him, returned to rest upon him.

For this reason, his brothers could not answer him because they were dismayed before him. They were distressed and regretful that they had caused the removal of the Divine Presence from him through causing him anguish, for the Shechinah only dwells in joy, as our Sages taught. Yosef understood their response through their lack of answer, therefore he said "Hurry and go up to my father," etc., and this would cause the return of the Divine Presence to him.

Similarly, in this way, the holy tribes recognized from the angels that were created through Yosef's speech that it was all truth and his mouth matched his heart. This is why he said to them "Behold, your eyes see, and the eyes of my brother Binyamin... that it is my mouth speaking to you," for they could see with their eyes Yosef's words, meaning those angels that were created from his speech. From this they discerned that he spoke truth and his mouth matched his heart, and there was no aspect of falsehood or deception in his words, for if there were, it would have been evident in the angels created from his speech.

And regarding what they said that he showed them he was circumcised, one could say that the intention is not simply that he physically showed them his circumcision, but rather the intention refers to the mitzvah of milah (circumcision). He showed them the angels that were created from his mitzvah of milah and that he guarded his covenant, for one who damages his covenant, his foreskin extends. They discerned to know that the mitzvah was complete with him through seeing the holy angels created from his mitzvah of milah.

From this it was clarified to them that he was Yosef HaTzaddik, for such a reality doesn't exist among other people who are not from the seed of Yaakov Avinu, to have the mitzvah of milah in such completeness. It was completely verified to them that he was Yosef, and for this reason the verse repeats to say again "no man stood with him when Yosef made himself known to his brothers," hinting that only man did not stand with him, but those holy angels that were created from his actions and speech of Yosef HaTzaddik stood there.

From them it was verified to the holy tribes that Yosef was their brother, similar to what is written in Yalkut Reuveni (Parshat Vayeshev) that when the attribute of judgment prosecuted the tribes for the sin of selling Yosef, based on what is written "and one who steals a man and sells him, and he is found in his possession, shall surely be put to death," the Holy One Blessed be He responded that it says "steals a man," but Yosef was not a man but rather on the level of an angel. And in this way, the verse hints here "no man stood with him when Yosef made himself known to his brothers," but angels stood there, and through this it was verified to the tribes that he was their brother.

Our father Yaakov, peace be upon him, sent Yehudah ahead of him to prepare the way to Goshen, and to establish a Beis Medrash (house of study) as our Sages said. Seemingly, Yosef himself could have prepared this, or it could have been done through any of the other tribes, so why did he send Yehudah who was king?

It appears to be explained based on the Midrash regarding "and he saw the wagons that Yosef sent" - where were the wagons that Pharaoh sent? It teaches that those wagons that Pharaoh sent to carry him had idolatrous images engraved on them, so Yehudah stood up and burned them. This tribe was accustomed to burning avodah zarah (idolatry). The Yefeh Toar and Nitzotzei Kedushah questioned why Yosef didn't burn them himself, and they answered that since Yehudah was especially suited for this task, it was left to him. The Nitzotzei Kedushah elaborates based on the Midrash that "we are not as expert in the details of avodah zarah as our father Yaakov," and similarly, Yehudah was expert in the details of avodah zarah.

Therefore, Yaakov sent Yehudah because he could recognize and discern even hidden aspects of avodah zarah, including thoughts of idolatry, as that tribe was accustomed to burning avodah zarah. Since Yaakov wanted to establish a house from which Torah instruction would emanate, it required careful discrimination to ensure there would be no trace of avodah zarah, and only Yehudah was suited for this as mentioned above. Therefore, he specifically sent Yehudah to prepare the Beis Medrash, ensuring it would be completely free of any trace of avodah zarah, and from there Torah instruction would emerge.

From this, we can see how carefully one must guard against the ways of avodah zarah, requiring extra wisdom to understand, distinguish, and separate from them. This connects to the halachah they taught: "When do we make the blessing over fire at the conclusion of Shabbos? Our rabbis taught that we don't make the blessing until we can benefit from its light." This is because extra recognition is needed to make distinctions, and where did they learn this from? From the Holy One, Blessed be He, as it says, "And God saw the light that it was good" and afterward "God separated between the light and the darkness." For this reason, he sent Yehudah ahead, because extra discernment was needed to prepare a Beis Medrash that would be suitable and worthy for Torah instruction to emanate from it.

We can explain the verse "to establish for you a remnant in the land, etc." based on what is said in the Gemara regarding ribis (interest) [Bava Metzia 75b]: Those who transgress the negative commandment are the lender, borrower, guarantor, and witnesses. Abaye said the lender transgresses all [prohibitions], etc., while the guarantor and witnesses only transgress "you shall not place upon him interest."

The Gemara [62a] asks: While all others perform an action, what action do the witnesses perform? Rather, is it not that the very act of establishing [the loan] is significant? Thus, even though the guarantor and witnesses didn't perform an actual deed in the matter itself, because the transaction was completed through them, they are liable for the prohibition of "you shall not place," with the root of the action being included in the word "placing."

Similarly, in our matter, Yosef HaTzaddik preceded going to Egypt to prepare a place for Bnei Yisrael so they could maintain their kedushah (holiness) in Egyptian exile, which was the ervat ha'aretz (most defiled land) and extremely contaminated. Through the power of his kedushah and the trials he withstood and overcame, and by becoming ruler over the sar (angel) of Egypt, he weakened the power of tumah (impurity) and klipot (negative forces) at their root.

Through this, Israel merited to be protected from immorality in Egypt - "Bnei Yisrael entered and Bnei Yisrael left" - and not one of them was born from improper relations, as our Sages said. Moreover, Yosef HaTzaddik prepared a power of salvation for future generations until the final exile, so that Israel could overcome and withstand the trials of exile and maintain their kedushah even in the terrible lowliness of ikveta d'meshicha (the footsteps of Mashiach), as the Egyptian exile is the root of all exiles.

The holy Avot and Shevatim were the root of all Jewish souls throughout the generations, and whatever exists in the branch exists in the root. Therefore, through their holy actions, they opened a channel and prepared strength for all generations of Israel. This is the meaning of "to establish for you a remnant in the land and to sustain you for a great deliverance" - that Yosef HaTzaddik established a foundation and root of strength for all generations of Israel. This is the holy spark which is hidden within the nefesh (soul) of every Jew, inherited from our holy forefathers. At first, it is only at the level of a "remnant," but afterward, the boundary of kedushah expands "to sustain you for a great deliverance."

Our Sages of blessed memory said in the Midrash that no one could take wagons out of Egypt without Pharaoh's permission. Even those wagons that Yosef sent needed to be with Pharaoh's permission. Therefore, Pharaoh needed to say to Yosef "you have commanded by my word," to tell them that it was with his permission. For if they didn't tell our father Yaakov that they were sent with Pharaoh's permission, our father Yaakov would not agree to use the wagons, even for their wives and children, as this would constitute rebellion against the kingdom. Pharaoh wanted them to use his wagons as mentioned above, therefore he commanded to tell Yaakov that they were sent with Pharaoh's permission.

Thus, even though Yehudah burned Pharaoh's wagons in their place and they never reached Yaakov, nevertheless the Torah later mentions "and the children of Israel carried... their children and their wives in the wagons that Pharaoh sent," since it had to be with Pharaoh's permission, it was as if Pharaoh had sent them. And when they came to their father Yaakov with the wagons that Yosef sent, he saw that they were completely free from any trace of avodah zarah (idolatry). He understood this was from the power of Yosef HaTzaddik, for it is explained in the aforementioned Midrash that no other person was as expert in the minutiae of avodah zarah as Yaakov Avinu, and Yosef learned from him, as Yaakov Avinu transmitted all his wisdom to him, as our Sages said. Therefore, he was able to discern that the wagons would be clean from all traces of avodah zarah.

In the previous verse it states "I will sustain you there... for there are yet five years of famine, lest you come to poverty, you, and your household, and all that you have." However, seemingly Yosef's promise to feed and sustain them for five more years wasn't fulfilled, as Chazal say that when Yaakov Avinu came to Egypt, the famine immediately ceased in his merit.

It's possible that Yosef knew through Ruach HaKodesh (Divine inspiration) that the famine would end with Yaakov's arrival, as Chazal say in Pirkei D'Rabbi Eliezer that Ruach HaKodesh guided him from his youth until his death. If so, why did he say "I will sustain you... for five more years of famine" when his vow wasn't fulfilled?

For this, he already received reward for all five years even though the famine ended earlier, as explained in the aforementioned Sifri that one receives reward for the declaration even if unable to complete the action.

So his brothers wouldn't question how he was permitted to make such a vow, since it's forbidden to make vows except by saying "Harei Zu" (behold this is), we explained earlier that it's permitted with proper intention. Therefore, he immediately said "Your eyes see... my mouth speaking to you," which Chazal interpret as "as my mouth is, so is my heart" - meaning his thoughts and intentions were proper, and in such a case it's a mitzvah to make a vow and one receives reward for the declaration as if for the action.

There are those who think that maintaining a large institution with great expenses through limited means and a small number of God-fearing supporters is anyway miraculous, and therefore rely on miracles, thinking they don't need to take action as the miracle will come regardless. But this isn't correct, as we don't rely on miracles. Only through the power of Jews giving with self-sacrifice and proper intention can we exist beyond natural means.

However, the question still seemingly remains unresolved - how could Joseph stumble in something that caused him such pain? For even if he hinted about Mordechai's future emergence from Benjamin, this wouldn't suffice, as perhaps they wouldn't understand the prophetic hint and jealousy wouldn't be removed from their hearts. Thus the question returns: how could he cause jealousy among the brothers?

Rather, we must say that Joseph recognized in them that they understood the hints in his actions. Therefore, there was no place for jealousy among the brothers since he was making an allusion for future generations of Israel. In any case, it is clear that they perceived and saw in Joseph that he was a great person, and the truth is that all of Joseph's actions were symbolic representations for future generations. Through this, he drew the matter from potential into actuality, as the Ramban explains (in Parshat Lech Lecha) that all the actions of the holy forefathers were in this manner, see there.

"And he saw the wagons (agalot) that Yosef had sent, etc." Rashi explains that he gave them a sign regarding what they were studying when they separated - the passage of the eglah arufah (broken-necked heifer). This is what is meant by "and he saw the wagons that Yosef had sent."

The Baalei HaTosafot wrote regarding Rashi's explanation that it needs further clarification. They explained that when Yaakov separated from his father, he accompanied him, as it is written "and he sent him," which refers to accompaniment (levayah). Yosef said to him, "Return," and Yaakov replied, "My son, the mitzvah of accompaniment is so great that an entire passage was added to the Torah because of it, as it is written 'our hands did not spill this blood.' It is difficult according to both explanations to interpret "agalot" (wagons) as relating to "eglah" (heifer), etc., as the Baalei HaTosafot conclude. The holy tribes [Shevatim HaKedoshim] certainly had the ability to perceive the nature of the angels that were created from Yosef's speech, and at what spiritual level and status he stood. However, as long as Yosef had not revealed himself to them, this knowledge was concealed from them. This was ordained from Heaven that they should not recognize that he was Yosef, similar to how we find that the Holy One Blessed be He concealed from our father Avraham, peace be upon him, the matter of the Binding of Yitzchak [Akeidah], even though Hashem had revealed to him all the mysteries of wisdom.
